elements.content: The ligand 4bpytm [4bpytm = bis(4-pyridylthio)methane] in strongly acidic media afforded H24bpytm(NO3)2. The reaction of CuCl2.2H2O with 4bpytm at low pH values afforded three supramolecular compounds: H24bpytm[CuCl4] (1) and the monomeric complexes [CuCl3(H4bpytm)(4bpytm)] (2) and [CuCl2(H4bpytm)2]·Cl2 (3). Nevertheless, the same reaction using aprotic solvents under microwave irradiation afforded the 1D coordination polymers [CuCl2(4bpytm)]·2dmf (4.dmf) and [CuCl2(4bpytm)]·2dmso (4.dmso). The 3D supramolecular organization through weak interactions has been analyzed for all of the compounds, and their thermal behavior and structural dynamics after solvent release were also investigated for 4.dmf and 4.dmso. X-ray structural analysis of these complexes showed that the synthetic conditions used represent an effective method to obtain metal−organic square grid networks with cavities.

elements.content: Metallosupramolecular chemistry involving the spontaneous self-assembly of precursor metal ions and organic ligands is a rapidly developing research area. Interest in these systems is justified by the rich diversity of structural motifs, which range from simple zero-dimensional oligomers to three-dimensional polymers, and the numerous potential applications, which include catalysis, sorption, photochemistry, and magnetism. The choice of organic ligand is crucial in the construction of specific metallosupramolecular architectures because these are the organic units that serve to connect the metal centers and propagate the structural information expressed in metal coordination preferences throughout the extended structure. Therefore, once suitable metal ions are recognized, variations in the geometry, size, and relative orientation of the donor groups of the organic linker can afford a tremendous breadth of structural motifs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metallosupramolecular chemistry involving the spontaneous self-assembly of precursor metal ions and organic ligands is a rapidly developing research area. Interest in these systems is justified by the rich diversity of structural motifs, which range from simple zero-dimensional oligomers to three-dimensional polymers, and the numerous potential applications, which include catalysis, sorption, photochemistry, and magnetism. The choice of organic ligand is crucial in the construction of specific metallosupramolecular architectures because these are the organic units that serve to connect the metal centers and propagate the structural information expressed in metal coordination preferences throughout the extended structure. Therefore, once suitable metal ions are recognized, variations in the geometry, size, and relative orientation of the donor groups of the organic linker can afford a tremendous breadth of structural motifs.

elements.content: Thioether ligands containing a flexible backbone are among the most important types of organic ligands because their flexibility and conformational freedom allow for greater structural diversity. Heterocycle-based thioether ligands bearing S- and N-coordinating sites tend to coordinate metals with different modes, thus forming a wide variety of structurally interesting supramolecular entities. We are currently interested in the metallosupramolecular chemistry of this kind of ligand, and we previously investigated the reactivity of the bis(4-pyridylthio)methane (4bpytm) ligand toward different copper(II) and silver(I) salts with organic and inorganic anions. In this previous study, 4bpytm was successfully used to construct complexes with various structures that included discrete molecules as well as one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers. In all of these compounds, the cation was coordinated preferentially by the nitrogen atoms of 4bpytm, and in only one casea silver(I) compoundwas the thioether sulfur involved in the coordination of the metal. During these investigations, we also observed that the halide compounds [CuX2(4bpytm)2], X = Cl and Br, are 2D interpenetrated coordination polymers. Although interpenetration has become well-documented in recent years, the factors that control the observed degree of interpenetration in the self-assembly process remain largely unknown. Numerous factors such as the nature of the counterion, pH values, temperature, and solvents could affect the final structure. As a continuation of our studies aimed at understanding the ability of 4bpytm to produce new metallosupramolecular compounds, we describe here an investigation that involved several as yet uninvestigated parameters such as low pH values and the use of different solvents such as dmf and dmso. Changes in the pH were used to obtain different protonation levels for 4bpytm, and the N−H···N and N−H···Cl interactions were exploited as new synthons. The study of the pH effect on the assembly of metal−organic architectures to form nets as a result of metal−ligand and hydrogen bond interactions has attracted attention over the last years. Furthermore, the use of different solvents represents a suitable way to avoid interpenetration in coordination polymers. In this respect, dmf and dmso were used in the synthesis and crystallization of [CuCl2(4bpytm)]·solv. The thermal and chemical stabilities of these solvates were also studied.

elements.content: 4bpytm was prepared as described previously. The other starting materials and solvents were obtained commercially and were used as supplied. Syntheses under microwave irradiation were performed in an adapted domestic microwave oven. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, and S) were carried out with a Fisons EA-1108 microanalyzer. Melting points (mp) were determined on a Gallenkamp MBF-595 apparatus. IR spectra were recorded from KBr discs (4000−400 cm−1) on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrophotometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra of a solution of H24bpytm(NO3)2 in dmso-d 6 were recorded on a Bruker ARX400 spectrometer, and chemical shifts are reported relative to tetramethylsilane. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a SETSYS Evolution Setaram thermogravimetric analyzer under a flow of N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min −1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was carried out using a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) over the range 5.0−60.0° in steps of 0.20° (2θ) with a count time per step of 5.0s.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

4bpytm was prepared as described previously. The other starting materials and solvents were obtained commercially and were used as supplied. Syntheses under microwave irradiation were performed in an adapted domestic microwave oven. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, and S) were carried out with a Fisons EA-1108 microanalyzer. Melting points (mp) were determined on a Gallenkamp MBF-595 apparatus. IR spectra were recorded from KBr discs (4000-400 cm-1) on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrophotometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra of a solution of H24bpytm(NO3)2 in dmso-d 6 were recorded on a Bruker ARX400 spectrometer, and chemical shifts are reported relative to tetramethylsilane. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a SETSYS Evolution Setaram thermogravimetric analyzer under a flow of N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min -1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was carried out using a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) over the range 5.0-60.0° in steps of 0.20° (2θ) with a count time per step of 5.0s.

elements.content: Concentrated HNO3 (2 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of 4bpytm (0.9 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of EtOH/H2O (20 mL). The solution was heated under reflux for 12 h, and the final pH was 0.26. Crystals were obtained after the mother liquor was stored for 1 day at 4 °C. Data: yield, 95%; mp 217 °C. Anal. calcd for C11H12N4S2O6: C, 36.4; H, 3.4; N, 15.2; S, 15.0%. Found: C, 36.4; H, 3.4; N, 15.5; S, 15.5%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3160−3000 b, 1578 s, 1487 m, 1472 m, 1381 s, 1201 m, 734 m, 486 m. 1H NMR (dmso-d 6, δ ppm): 5.34 [s, 2H, C(6)H2], 7.98 (d, 4H, H-2, H-5), 8.74 (s, 4H, H-3, H-4). 13C NMR (dmso-d 6, δ ppm): 40.1 C(6), 141.1 C(2) and C(5), 122.8 C(1), 158.6 C(3) and C(4).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Compounds

H24bpytm(NO3)2 

Concentrated HNO3 (2 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of 4bpytm (0.9 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of EtOH/H2O (20 mL). The solution was heated under reflux for 12 h, and the final pH was 0.26. Crystals were obtained after the mother liquor was stored for 1 day at 4 °C. Data: yield, 95%; mp 217 °C. Anal. calcd for C11H12N4S2O6: C, 36.4; H, 3.4; N, 15.2; S, 15.0%. Found: C, 36.4; H, 3.4; N, 15.5; S, 15.5%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3160-3000 b, 1578 s, 1487 m, 1472 m, 1381 s, 1201 m, 734 m, 486 m. 1H NMR (dmso-d 6, δ ppm): 5.34 [s, 2H, C(6)H2], 7.98 (d, 4H, H-2, H-5), 8.74 (s, 4H, H-3, H-4). 13C NMR (dmso-d 6, δ ppm): 40.1 C(6), 141.1 C(2) and C(5), 122.8 C(1), 158.6 C(3) and C(4).

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained by reaction of 4bpytm (0.137 g, 0.586 mmol) and CuCl2·2H2O (0.050 g, 0.293 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of water/absolute ethanol (20 mL). A 0.3 M concentration of HCl (3 mL) was added dropwise to the mixture to give a final pH of 1.25. The initial green precipitate was dissolved when HCl was added dropwise giving rise to a blue solution. This solution was stirred for 24 h. Orange crystals were obtained from the resulting solution by slow evaporation (6 days) at room temperature. Data: yield, 90%; mp 230 °C. Anal. calcd for C11H12Cl4N2S2Cu: C, 29.9; H, 2.7; N, 6.3; S, 14.5%. Found: C, 30.7; H, 2.8; N, 6.7; S, 15.0%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3182−2875 b, 1587 s, 1491 m, 1470 m, 1203 m, 735 m, 482 m.
elements.clean_text:
H24bpytm[CuCl4] (1)

Compound 1 was obtained by reaction of 4bpytm (0.137 g, 0.586 mmol) and CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.050 g, 0.293 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of water/absolute ethanol (20 mL). A 0.3 M concentration of HCl (3 mL) was added dropwise to the mixture to give a final pH of 1.25. The initial green precipitate was dissolved when HCl was added dropwise giving rise to a blue solution. This solution was stirred for 24 h. Orange crystals were obtained from the resulting solution by slow evaporation (6 days) at room temperature. Data: yield, 90%; mp 230 °C. Anal. calcd for C11H12Cl4N2S2Cu: C, 29.9; H, 2.7; N, 6.3; S, 14.5%. Found: C, 30.7; H, 2.8; N, 6.7; S, 15.0%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3182-2875 b, 1587 s, 1491 m, 1470 m, 1203 m, 735 m, 482 m.

elements.content: A solution of 4bpytm (1.6 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was slowly added to a solution of CuCl2·2H2O (1 mmol) in methanol (7 mL). Oxalic acid (1 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was added to the reaction mixture. A green precipitate, containing oxalate and copper ions but with an undefined stoichiometry, was immediately filtered off. Single crystals of 2 were obtained from the resulting green solution by slow evaporation (2 days) at room temperature. Data: yield, 8%; mp 215 °C. Anal. calcd for C22H21N4S4Cl3Cu: C, 41.3; H, 3.3; N, 8.8; S, 20.0%. Found: C, 41.5; H, 3.4; N, 8.9; S, 20.4%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3074−2924 b 1594 s, 1535 m, 1481 m, 1202 m, 1019 m, 811 m, 731 m, 498 m.
elements.clean_text:
[CuCl3(H4bpytm)(4bpytm)] (2)

A solution of 4bpytm (1.6 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was slowly added to a solution of CuCl2⋅2H2O (1 mmol) in methanol (7 mL). Oxalic acid (1 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was added to the reaction mixture. A green precipitate, containing oxalate and copper ions but with an undefined stoichiometry, was immediately filtered off. Single crystals of 2 were obtained from the resulting green solution by slow evaporation (2 days) at room temperature. Data: yield, 8%; mp 215 °C. Anal. calcd for C22H21N4S4Cl3Cu: C, 41.3; H, 3.3; N, 8.8; S, 20.0%. Found: C, 41.5; H, 3.4; N, 8.9; S, 20.4%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3074-2924 b 1594 s, 1535 m, 1481 m, 1202 m, 1019 m, 811 m, 731 m, 498 m.

elements.content: Compounds 4.dmso and 4.dmf were heated in an oven at 150 °C for 15 min/1 h (respectively) to give desolvated green powders. In each case, the powder (5 mg) was dissolved in acetone (10 mL) and lactic acid (1 mL, 11 mmol). Blue single crystals of 3 appeared after 3 days at room temperature. Data: mp 235 °C. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3404−2611 b, 1581 s, 1462 m, 1425 m, 1228 m, 1049 m, 808 m, 737 m, 502 m. Insufficient crystals were obtained for elemental analysis or a meaningful estimation of yield.
elements.clean_text:
[CuCl2(H4bpytm)2]⋅Cl2 (3)

Compounds 4.dmso and 4.dmf were heated in an oven at 150 °C for 15 min/1 h (respectively) to give desolvated green powders. In each case, the powder (5 mg) was dissolved in acetone (10 mL) and lactic acid (1 mL, 11 mmol). Blue single crystals of 3 appeared after 3 days at room temperature. Data: mp 235 °C. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3404-2611 b, 1581 s, 1462 m, 1425 m, 1228 m, 1049 m, 808 m, 737 m, 502 m. Insufficient crystals were obtained for elemental analysis or a meaningful estimation of yield.

elements.content: 4bpytm (0.213 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.213 mmol), dmf (4 mL), and EtOH (2 mL) were added to a Schlenk tube, which was then placed in a microwave oven. The mixture was irradiated for 90 s at 700 W. The resulting blue solution was allowed to cool down to room temperature, and blue crystals of 4.dmf were obtained rapidly. Data: yield, 90%; mp 229 °C. Anal. calcd for C17H24N4S2O2Cl2Cu: C, 39.6; H, 4.7; N, 10.9; S, 12.4%. Found: C, 39.5; H, 4.5; N, 10.6; S, 12.9%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3434 s, 1655 s, 1596 s, 1538 m, 1487 m, 1422 m, 1223 m, 1028 m, 809 m, 732 m, 504 m.

The resulting blue solution was allowed to cool down to room temperature, and blue crystals of 4.dmf were obtained rapidly. Data: yield, 90%; mp 229 °C. Anal. calcd for C17H24N4S2O2Cl2Cu: C, 39.6; H, 4.7; N, 10.9; S, 12.4%. Found: C, 39.5; H, 4.5; N, 10.6; S, 12.9%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3434 s, 1655 s, 1596 s, 1538 m, 1487 m, 1422 m, 1223 m, 1028 m, 809 m, 732 m, 504 m.

Anal. calcd for C15H22N2S4O2Cl2Cu: C, 34.3; H, 4.2; N, 5.3; S, 24.4%. Found: C, 34.3; H, 4.3; N, 5.3; S, 24.8%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3430 s, 1598 s, 1540 m, 1427 m, 1227 m, 1029 m, 804 m, 733 m, 505 m.

elements.content: Crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The frames were integrated with the Bruker SAINT software package, and the data were corrected for absorption using the program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters by full-matrix least-squares calculations on F 2 using the program SHELXL97. Hydrogen atoms were inserted at calculated positions and constrained with isotropic thermal parameters, except for the hydrogen atoms of the pyridine groups that were located in a difference Fourier map. These C−H hydrogen atoms were refined using a “riding” model (AFIX 43). In H24bpytm(NO3)2, the N−H hydrogen atom was isotropically refined but with the isotropic factor depending of the nitrogen atom in compounds 1, 2, and 3. In 4.dmso, the contribution of solvent molecules of crystallization to the diffraction patterns could not be rigorously included in the crystallographic calculations, and this was consequently removed with the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. The disorder of dmf atoms in 4.dmf may be modulled including common anisotropic factors for the atoms belonging to the solvent. The program PLATON was also used for special computations for the crystal structure discussions. Drawings were produced with MERCURY. Crystal data and structure refinement data are listed in Table . The structural data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) with reference numbers 770396 [H24bpytm(NO3)2] 770397 (1), 770398 (2), 770399 (3), 770400 (4.dmf), and 770401 (4.dmso).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The frames were integrated with the Bruker SAINT software package, and the data were corrected for absorption using the program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters by full-matrix least-squares calculations on F 2 using the program SHELXL97. Hydrogen atoms were inserted at calculated positions and constrained with isotropic thermal parameters, except for the hydrogen atoms of the pyridine groups that were located in a difference Fourier map. These C-H hydrogen atoms were refined using a "riding" model (AFIX 43). In H24bpytm(NO3)2, the N-H hydrogen atom was isotropically refined but with the isotropic factor depending of the nitrogen atom in compounds 1, 2, and 3. In 4.dmso, the contribution of solvent molecules of crystallization to the diffraction patterns could not be rigorously included in the crystallographic calculations, and this was consequently removed with the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. The disorder of dmf atoms in 4.dmf may be modulled including common anisotropic factors for the atoms belonging to the solvent. The program PLATON was also used for special computations for the crystal structure discussions. Drawings were produced with MERCURY. Crystal data and structure refinement data are listed in Table . The structural data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) with reference numbers 770396 [H24bpytm(NO3)2] 770397 (1), 770398 (2), 770399 (3), 770400 (4.dmf), and 770401 (4.dmso).

Oxidative cleavage of the disulfide group of the analogous 4,4′-dipyridyldisulfide ligand to 4-pyridylsulfonateeven under mild conditionshas been reported previously. However, the ligand 4bpytm has proven to be a very stable compound in the presence of oxidizing agents such as nitric acid. Despite this, both pyridine groups of 4bpytm are protonated under these conditions, and H24bpytm(NO3)2 is obtained. The reaction of 4bpytm with CuCl2·2H2O under different synthetic conditions yielded different protonated systems (1, 2, and 3) as well as the 1D coordination polymers 4.dmf and 4.dmso. A general reaction scheme is shown in Scheme . Microanalysis confirmed that in each case, the 4bpytm ligand-to-metal ratio was conserved in these complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Oxidative cleavage of the disulfide group of the analogous 4,4'-dipyridyldisulfide ligand to 4-pyridylsulfonateeven under mild conditionshas been reported previously. However, the ligand 4bpytm has proven to be a very stable compound in the presence of oxidizing agents such as nitric acid. Despite this, both pyridine groups of 4bpytm are protonated under these conditions, and H24bpytm(NO3)2 is obtained. The reaction of 4bpytm with CuCl2⋅2H2O under different synthetic conditions yielded different protonated systems (1, 2, and 3) as well as the 1D coordination polymers 4.dmf and 4.dmso. A general reaction scheme is shown in Scheme . Microanalysis confirmed that in each case, the 4bpytm ligand-to-metal ratio was conserved in these complexes.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2010-004566_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

An X-ray diffraction study confirmed that protonation of both pyridine groups takes place in H24bpytm(NO3)2 obtained using HNO3. A particularly interesting property of H24bpytm(NO3)2 is the very different solubility of this new compound when compared to 4bpytm. The diprotonated form is soluble in water but insoluble in chlorinated solvents, acetone, methanol, and ethanol. Furthermore, analysis of the crystal structure showed that the N−H+ group is very active in the formation of hydrogen bonds. This finding encouraged us to test the effect of different acidic media on the system CuCl2/4bpytm. As reported previously, the hydrogen bonding acceptor capacity of chloride coordinated to metal centers is dramatically enhanced relative to organochloride. Thus, the compound H24bpytm[CuCl4] (1) was obtained in the presence of hydrochloric acid, and as expected, the N−H···Cl−Cu hydrogen bond is the predominant interaction in the formation of the net.
elements.clean_text: An X-ray diffraction study confirmed that protonation of both pyridine groups takes place in H24bpytm(NO3)2 obtained using HNO3. A particularly interesting property of H24bpytm(NO3)2 is the very different solubility of this new compound when compared to 4bpytm. The diprotonated form is soluble in water but insoluble in chlorinated solvents, acetone, methanol, and ethanol. Furthermore, analysis of the crystal structure showed that the N-H+ group is very active in the formation of hydrogen bonds. This finding encouraged us to test the effect of different acidic media on the system CuCl2/4bpytm. As reported previously, the hydrogen bonding acceptor capacity of chloride coordinated to metal centers is dramatically enhanced relative to organochloride. Thus, the compound H24bpytm[CuCl4] (1) was obtained in the presence of hydrochloric acid, and as expected, the N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl-Cu hydrogen bond is the predominant interaction in the formation of the net.

elements.content: The CuCl2/4bpytm system in the presence of weaker acids, but with sources of potential chelate proligands such as oxalic or lactic acids, afforded low yields of the neutral complexes [CuCl3(H4bpytm)(4bpytm)] (2) and [CuCl2(H4bpytm)2]Cl2 (3), respectively (note that 3 was obtained by treatment of the resulting material from the previously desolvated 4.dmf or 4.dmso). The ability to undergo protonation is also apparent in the formation of these compounds, but in both cases, the monoprotonated coordinated ligand, (H4bpytm)+, associates the molecules through N−H···N and N−H···Cl−Cu interactions. All of these findings suggest that an acidic medium may be used to control the degree of polymerization of the system 4bpytm/CuCl2·2H2O.
elements.clean_text: The CuCl2/4bpytm system in the presence of weaker acids, but with sources of potential chelate proligands such as oxalic or lactic acids, afforded low yields of the neutral complexes [CuCl3(H4bpytm)(4bpytm)] (2) and [CuCl2(H4bpytm)2]Cl2 (3), respectively (note that 3 was obtained by treatment of the resulting material from the previously desolvated 4.dmf or 4.dmso). The ability to undergo protonation is also apparent in the formation of these compounds, but in both cases, the monoprotonated coordinated ligand, (H4bpytm)+, associates the molecules through N-H⋅⋅⋅N and N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl-Cu interactions. All of these findings suggest that an acidic medium may be used to control the degree of polymerization of the system 4bpytm/CuCl2⋅2H2O.

elements.content: In previous work, we observed that the use of these building blocks gives rise to 2D metal−organic square grid networks [CuX2(4bpytm)2] (X = Cl and Br) that are interpenetrated and, as such, do not possess channels or cavities (Figure ). This interpenetration appears to mitigate the inefficient packing due to the presence of voids in the structure. To avoid the degree of interpenetration and obtain structures with cavities, we studied the effect of solvents, which can act as templates or as guest molecules in the resulting grid network. Two solvents (dmf and dmso) with well-known ability to act as guests in the formation of metallo-organic frameworks were tested. Conventional synthesis afforded powdered solids that proved difficult to characterize. However, [CuCl2(4bpytm)]·2dmf and [CuCl2(4bpytm)]·2dmso (4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively) were obtained in very good yield as single crystals after cooling the solution obtained under microwave irradiation. The microwave synthetic method provides an efficient way to synthesize pure materials due to its high efficiency, leading to a dramatic reduction in reaction times, impurity-free products, and also acceleration of the crystallization process. We performed the synthesis with CuCl2·2H2O using EtOH and the corresponding coordinative solvent.

We performed the synthesis with CuCl2⋅2H2O using EtOH and the corresponding coordinative solvent.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of these compounds show the characteristic absorption bands of the 4bpytm ligand, and the spectra are barely modified upon protonation and formation of the corresponding Cu(II) complexes. H24bpytm(NO3)2 and the compounds 1, 2, and 3 show several bands in the range 3200−2600 cm−1 due to ν(N−H) vibrations. Hydrogen bonding in H24bpytm(NO3)2, 1, 2, and 3 shifts the N−H deformation bands to higher frequencies than the usually observed (3500−3300 cm−1). These bands have a broad adsorption and present a medium-to-strong intensity. Despite the different strength of the N−H···X (X = O, Cl, or N) hydrogen bonds, all of the spectra present two overlapping bands, one broad band at low frequencies and the other formed by a collection of sharper bands at high frequencies. An intense absorption is also observed at 1381 cm−1 in H24bpytm(NO3)2 due to the nitrate anion. The spectra of complexes 4.dmf and 4.dmso display absorption bands due to the solvent molecules present in the framework: a ν(CO) band at 1657 cm−1 in 4.dmf and ν(SO) bands at 1072, 1055, and 1018 cm−1 in 4.dmso.
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectra of these compounds show the characteristic absorption bands of the 4bpytm ligand, and the spectra are barely modified upon protonation and formation of the corresponding Cu(II) complexes. H24bpytm(NO3)2 and the compounds 1, 2, and 3 show several bands in the range 3200-2600 cm-1 due to ν(N-H) vibrations. Hydrogen bonding in H24bpytm(NO3)2, 1, 2, and 3 shifts the N-H deformation bands to higher frequencies than the usually observed (3500-3300 cm-1). These bands have a broad adsorption and present a medium-to-strong intensity. Despite the different strength of the N-H⋅⋅⋅X (X = O, Cl, or N) hydrogen bonds, all of the spectra present two overlapping bands, one broad band at low frequencies and the other formed by a collection of sharper bands at high frequencies. An intense absorption is also observed at 1381 cm-1 in H24bpytm(NO3)2 due to the nitrate anion. The spectra of complexes 4.dmf and 4.dmso display absorption bands due to the solvent molecules present in the framework: a ν(CO) band at 1657 cm-1 in 4.dmf and ν(SO) bands at 1072, 1055, and 1018 cm-1 in 4.dmso.

elements.content: All of the compounds included in this work were isolated as single crystals, and their X-ray structures were determined. The asymmetric nature of the conformation adopted for 4bpytm in the structures (point group C 2) explains why all compounds crystallize in the C2/c space group (Table ). In fact, the −CH2− carbon atom lies on the 2-fold axis in the structures of H24bpytm(NO3)2, 4.dmf and 4.dmso, while this position is occupied by the copper atom in 2 and 3. In 2, this position is also occupied by the chloride atom, and as a result, the protonated nitrogen atom and the corresponding hydrogen atom are distributed over two symmetrically equivalent positions, thus giving a fixed occupancy factor of 50%.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Studies

All of the compounds included in this work were isolated as single crystals, and their X-ray structures were determined. The asymmetric nature of the conformation adopted for 4bpytm in the structures (point group C 2) explains why all compounds crystallize in the C2/c space group (Table ). In fact, the -CH2- carbon atom lies on the 2-fold axis in the structures of H24bpytm(NO3)2, 4.dmf and 4.dmso, while this position is occupied by the copper atom in 2 and 3. In 2, this position is also occupied by the chloride atom, and as a result, the protonated nitrogen atom and the corresponding hydrogen atom are distributed over two symmetrically equivalent positions, thus giving a fixed occupancy factor of 50%.

elements.content: Furthermore, the metal center and the organic and inorganic ligands remain the same in all compounds [except H24bpytm(NO3)2], but they combine to give different superstructures. If supramolecular isomerism is defined as the ability of a network to be generated by different supramolecular synthons or molecular assemblies, then these systems can be considered as supramolecular isomers generated by the same building blocks but forming different networks. The compounds 4.dmf and 4.dmso present the same crystalline form but have different guest solvent molecules, meaning that they could be considered as pseudopolymorphs. The different structural motifs (Scheme ) lead to the formation of supramolecular architectures where interpenetration is always avoided, and furthermore, different degrees of packing are achieved.

The crystal structures of 1 and 3 consist of cations formed by protonation of the original 4bpytm ligand and different anions. The (H24bpytm)2+ cation appears in H24bpytm(NO3)2 and 1, whereas the (H4bpytm)+ cation is present in 2 and 3. Nitrate, [CuCl4]2−, and chloride are the anions that surround the cations in H24bpytm(NO3)2, 1, and 3, respectively. On the other hand, monoprotonated and neutral ligands are present in [CuCl3(H4bpytm)(4bpytm)] (2).

On the other hand, monoprotonated and neutral ligands are present in [CuCl3(H4bpytm)(4bpytm)] (2).

elements.content: Protonation of 4bpytm causes slight changes in the distances and angles related to the pyridine rings with respect to those in the free ligand and also leads to appreciable differences in the value of the torsion angles of the C−S−C−S bridge. Whereas 2 has values of 71.0(2) and 74.18(2)° and 3 has values of 83.15(5) and 79.51(5)°, the values are close to that in the free ligand [73.73(7)°], and the main differences are present in the diprotonated compounds. It is worth noting that the value of 58.07(3)° for H24bpytm(NO3)2 is the smallest found in 4bpytm systems to date, and compound 1, with values of 170.90(2) and 80.99(2)°, has the largest angles observed. These angles correspond to a GG conformation in all cases expect for 1, which corresponds to the less common TG conformation. In accordance with this situation, the intramolecular N···N distances are in the range 9.137−9.754 Å except for H24bpytm(NO3)2, which has a lower value of 7.801 Å.

elements.content: The partial protonation of the coordinated ligand means that 4bpytm acts as a monodentate terminal ligand in 2 and 3, and this precludes the polymerization observed in [CuX2(4bpytm)2], in which the ligand adopts the typical bis-monodentate bridging (μ-κN:κN′) coordination mode. A terminal monodentate coordination mode has only been observed previously in [Cu2(HL)4(4bpytm)3] (HL = lactate), in which the 4bpytm torsion angles are 177.6(6) and 74.2(6)° (TG conformation), that is, clearly higher than those found in 2 and 3.

A terminal monodentate coordination mode has only been observed previously in [Cu2(HL)4(4bpytm)3] (HL = lactate), in which the 4bpytm torsion angles are 177.6(6) and 74.2(6)° (TG conformation), that is, clearly higher than those found in 2 and 3.

elements.content: The copper(II) ion provided a wide variety of coordination geometries. Each metal complex shows a different coordination number (4, 5, and 6) and geometry, including tetrahedral, trigonal bipyramidal, and distorted octahedral coordination geometry (4 + 2). On the basis of these observations, it is apparent that the flexibility of the coordination environment of the metal center is essential to achieve this structural diversity.

On the basis of these observations, it is apparent that the flexibility of the coordination environment of the metal center is essential to achieve this structural diversity.

elements.content: In complex 1, the copper center is in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, with Cu−Cl distances in the range 2.1977(11)−2.2671(10) Å and Cl−Cu−Cl angles in the range 99.93(4)−131.12(4)°. In 2, the copper atom is coordinated by two pyridine nitrogen atoms from two 4bpytm ligands, with Cu−N distances of 2.020(2) Å, and by three chloride atoms, with Cu−Cl distances of 2.3312(13) and 2.3777(8) Å. These distances are in the expected range for this type of bond. The Addison parameter τ of 0.84 suggests that the coordination sphere around the copper atom adopts a trigonal bipyramidal geometry with the two nitrogen atoms and the three chloride atoms in apical and equatorial positions, respectively. The N−Cu−N angle is 176.26(14)°, and the Cl−Cu−Cl angles are 108.34(4) and 125.83(2)°. The copper atom in 3 is coordinated to two pyridine nitrogen atoms from two 4bpytm ligands, with a Cu−N distance of 1.995(5) Å, and four chloride atoms in an axially elongated (4 + 2) octahedral geometry. The Cu−Cl1 distances are in the typical range found in this kind of compounds, but the Cu−Cl2 distance is 3.0894(17) Å, which is slightly long but still shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of chloride and copper.

elements.content: Comparison of these structures with those of [CuCl2(4bpytm)2] reveals that protonation of the ligand has a profound effect on the final network due to the electronic reorganization that takes place. More specifically, the coordination environment of the metal center changes from an elongated octahedron (4 + 2 type) to a different coordination geometry in each case, and the protonation of 4bpytm allows the formation of hydrogen bonds involving the N−H groups as donors. This new coordination pattern does not allow the formation of the 2D metal−organic layers through CuCl2 units bridged by 4bpytm ligands that were found in [CuCl2(4bpytm)2].

elements.content: The (H24bpytm)2+ cations are connected by nitrate (Figure ) and [CuCl4]2− anions (Figure ) in H24bpytm(NO3)2 and 1, respectively. The cations are connected to give a 3D architecture by NH···X and CH···X interactions (Table ) involving the oxygen and chloride atoms of anions as acceptors and −NH and −CH groups of the 4bpytm molecule as donors.

Although anions have different characteristics such as size and geometry, the effect in the supramolecular organization is similar. In both cases, there are anionic molecules between cationic units, and these are linked through the aforementioned interactions to form zigzag chains along the c-axis in H24bpytm(NO3)2 (Figure ) and along the a-axis in 1 (Figure ). It is clear that the anions play a crucial role in the supramolecular assembly, but the strength of the interactions differs in each of the compounds. In H24bpytm(NO3)2, there is a hydrogen bond with an N···O distance of 2.749(5) Å and an almost linear N−H···O angle of 173(4)°, whereas in 1 the N···Cl distance is 3.142(4) Å with an angle of 169(5)°. As result, the same kinds of interactions lead to the supramolecular organization but are stronger in H24bpytm(NO3)2 than in 1.

elements.content: The resulting 3D architecture can be described as consisting of square grids in the ab and cb planes with the dimensions of the square cavity being approximately 13 Å × 11 Å and 4 Å × 4 Å in H24bpytm(NO3)2 and 1, respectively. These cavities have different sizes because they are formed by four protonated 4bpytm ligands in H24bpytm(NO3)2 (Figure ) and by two protonated ligands in 1 (Figure ). The very large cavities in H24bpytm(NO3)2 contain two (H24bpytm)2+ ions fixed to the grid by means of weak interactions that involve sulfur atoms (Figure ). These molecules are only weakly linked by CH···S (with C···S distances of 3.769 Å and a C−H···S angle of 148°; symmetry code: 1.5 − x, −1/2 + y, 1.5 − z) and S···O van der Waals interactions, with an S···O distance of 3.30 Å, similar to the sum of the corresponding van der Waals radii. The small cavities in 1 do not offer the possibility of being filled with guest molecules that interact with the host framework. The efficient packing of these 3D networks is also evident in the corresponding value of the Kitaigorodskii index, which is 73.4% in H24bpytm(NO3)2 and 70.4% in 1.

elements.content: The ligand is monoprotonated in 2 and 3. In 3, the cation [CuCl2(H4bpytm)2]2+ is surrounded by chloride anions in the second coordination sphere, whereas 2 is a neutral molecular compound. Nevertheless, both compounds form chains through N−H···X (X = N in 2 and Cl in 3) through moderate hydrogen bonds involving the protonated pyridine.

elements.content: In 2, each molecule interacts with two others along the c-axis through moderate N−H···N hydrogen bonds involving the N−H group of protonated pyridine ligand and another nitrogen belonging to a neighboring monomer (Table and Figure ). This situation generates chains, and each chain interacts with two adjacent ones through several weak CH···Cl hydrogen bonds, which involve the −CH2 methylene group, the −CH of the pyridine ring, and chloride atoms from neighboring monomers (Table ).

elements.content: As in the previous compounds, the anion plays a crucial role in the supramolecular organization in 3. The N−H···Cl2 interactions involving the N−H group of a protonated pyridine ligand and Cl2 atoms form double undulating chains along the c-axis. These chains interact with neighboring ones by means of weak CH···Cl hydrogen bonds (Table ) to form the 3D supramolecular organization. The resulting architecture can be described as an association of parallel chains in which the chloride anions are situated between the metalloorganic frameworks (Figure ).

elements.content: In complex 2, and in contrast to 3, the weak interactions form three interwoven chains that are associated into a 3D network, as shown in Figure . This situation generates a final supramolecular architecture in which copper and chloride atoms are oriented toward the outside of the interwoven chains. The molecular packing does not appear to be very efficient bearing in mind the Kitaigorodskii index of 66.6% for 2 and 69.6% for 3, both of which are lower than the value found for previously reported compounds.

elements.content: From the point of view of chirality, compound 3 is achiral with ligands of different helicity, and in 2, each monomer incorporates two molecules of 4bpytm ligand with the same helicity. As a result, the monomers with opposite helicity are connected to give a racemic supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: Compounds 4.dmf and 4.dmso are isostructural, as determined from the unit cell similarity index (Π = 0.005). These complexes can be considered as pseudopolymorphs because the structures present the same crystalline form but contain different solvents. The coordination environment of the copper atoms in 4.dmf is represented in Figure , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . The contribution of the disordered solvent in 4.dmso could not be rigorously included in the crystallographic calculations, and it was therefore removed from the structure. The two compounds are based on 1D chains and solvents of crystallization. Each copper atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms in trans positions from a 4bpytm ligand, with Cu−N distances of 1.992(6) and 1.979(4) Å, and by two chloride atoms also in trans positions, with Cu−Cl distances of 2.2718(9) and 2.2767(15) Å in 4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively. The cis N−Cu−Cl angles are 90.54(16) and 89.46(16)° in 4.dmf and 90.36(14) and 89.64(14)° in 4.dmso. These distances and angles are in the expected range for such coordination bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Structures of Solvates 4.dmf and 4.dmso 

Compounds 4.dmf and 4.dmso are isostructural, as determined from the unit cell similarity index (Π = 0.005). These complexes can be considered as pseudopolymorphs because the structures present the same crystalline form but contain different solvents. The coordination environment of the copper atoms in 4.dmf is represented in Figure , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . The contribution of the disordered solvent in 4.dmso could not be rigorously included in the crystallographic calculations, and it was therefore removed from the structure. The two compounds are based on 1D chains and solvents of crystallization. Each copper atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms in trans positions from a 4bpytm ligand, with Cu-N distances of 1.992(6) and 1.979(4) Å, and by two chloride atoms also in trans positions, with Cu-Cl distances of 2.2718(9) and 2.2767(15) Å in 4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively. The cis N-Cu-Cl angles are 90.54(16) and 89.46(16)° in 4.dmf and 90.36(14) and 89.64(14)° in 4.dmso. These distances and angles are in the expected range for such coordination bonds.

elements.content: In addition to these strong bonds, there are also two weak interactions with two oxygen atoms belonging to solvent molecules in an axially elongated (4 + 2) octahedral geometry [Odmf−Cu = 2.815(11) Å in 4.dmf]. In 4.dmso, the disorder observed in the dmso molecule suggests that this interaction is weaker.

elements.content: The ligand 4bpytm acts as an N,N′-bis(monodentate) bridge with a C−S−C−S torsion angle of 74.08 and 77.42° in 4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively. The torsion angles are slightly larger than those found in the free ligand and correspond to a GG conformation. In the polymers, the distances between two neighboring copper(II) ions through the 4bpytm ligand are 13.087 and 13.356 Å in 4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively. The chains are connected by means of different CH···Cl interactions that involve −CH groups of pyridine rings and a −CH2 methylene group belonging to the 4bpytm ligand, as well as interactions with chloride atoms of adjacent chains (Table ).

elements.content: In both compounds, these interactions are responsible for the formation of 2D layers that can be described as a rectangular grid network with Cu···Cu distances of 13.087 and 8.892 Å in 4.dmf and 13.366 and 8.351 Å in 4.dmso. The resulting cavities in these networks are filled by solvent molecules, and these are involved in different weak interactions with the metal−organic framework. In 4.dmf, the solvent molecules are linked to the network by means of several CH···O hydrogen bonds as well as the weak Cu···O interactions (Figure and Table ). The volume occupied by the solvent and its stabilizing effect on the network are also evident in the corresponding values of the Kitaigorodskii packing index: 45.2% when the solvent is omitted in 4.dmso, 66.6% when the solvent is included, and 43.4% when it is omitted in the calculation for 4.dmf. Both complexes possess cavities with effective dimensions that form infinite channels parallel to the c-axis (Figure ), and these channels contain columns of disordered solvent molecules. The parallel infinite layers of rectangular grids are eclipsed, and the resulting parallel channels are perpendicular to the planes of the rectangular grids. The solvents that fill the cavities of the networks can act as a template in the formation of the metallosupramolecular compounds, and these consequently contribute to the stability of the structure.

elements.content: The analysis of the crystal structures of 4.dmf and 4.dmso shows that the solvent molecules are located in channels that could allow the release of these solvent molecules. The thermogravimetric (TG) curves show similar weight loss behavior for both compounds with two successive events (). The first weight loss is assigned to the loss of trapped solvent molecules. Thermal analysis of 4.dmf shows that the first step starts at 130 °C with a weight loss of 26.6% and continues to 200 °C, which corresponds to the loss of two molecules of dmf (calcd 28.4%). The TGA study of 4.dmso shows a weight loss of 28.9% from 110 to 195 °C, which corresponds to two molecules of dmso (calcd 29.7%). The next weight loss occurred at 239 and 210 °C in 4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively. At these temperatures, the metal−organic frameworks begin to decompose.

Thermal Stability and Structural Dynamics

The analysis of the crystal structures of 4.dmf and 4.dmso shows that the solvent molecules are located in channels that could allow the release of these solvent molecules. The thermogravimetric (TG) curves show similar weight loss behavior for both compounds with two successive events (). The first weight loss is assigned to the loss of trapped solvent molecules. Thermal analysis of 4.dmf shows that the first step starts at 130 °C with a weight loss of 26.6% and continues to 200 °C, which corresponds to the loss of two molecules of dmf (calcd 28.4%). The TGA study of 4.dmso shows a weight loss of 28.9% from 110 to 195 °C, which corresponds to two molecules of dmso (calcd 29.7%). The next weight loss occurred at 239 and 210 °C in 4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively. At these temperatures, the metal-organic frameworks begin to decompose.

elements.content: Freshly ground samples of both compounds were heated in an oven at 150 °C for 1 h in the case of 4.dmf and for 15 min for 4.dmso to achieve expulsion of solvent molecules. The desolvation of the samples was confirmed by the weight loss, IR, elemental analysis, and also by the change in color from blue to pale green. The IR spectra of the initial solids show the characteristic bands of the solvent molecules, and these bands disappear completely on heating the compounds, suggesting the elimination of the solvent. The original and desolvated samples were characterized by XRPD at room temperature, and this showed that the desolvated materials cannot maintain the frameworks after removal of the guest molecule (Figures S5 and S6 in the ). IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis of the powdered material obtained after stirring the original 4.dmf and 4.dmso for 3 days in a mixture of toluene/methanol suggest that expulsion of the guest molecules is also achieved.

The original and desolvated samples were characterized by XRPD at room temperature, and this showed that the desolvated materials cannot maintain the frameworks after removal of the guest molecule (Figures S5 and S6 in the ). IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis of the powdered material obtained after stirring the original 4.dmf and 4.dmso for 3 days in a mixture of toluene/methanol suggest that expulsion of the guest molecules is also achieved.

elements.content: On leaving the desolvated material of 4.dmso in a chamber at 50 °C with dmso, it reverted to the crystalline solvated form. The XRPD pattern of the resulting material does not show significant differences as compared with that of the original material, and the thermogravimetric study shows the loss of two molecules of dmso at identical temperatures. The reversible structural transformation to guest-free compounds suggests that this compound could behave as a porous coordination polymer. A reversible transformation to the crystalline solvated form was not achieved in 4.dmf desolvated material.

Bearing this information in mind and to check if these compounds behave as porous coordination polymers, the desolvated materials were treated with different solvents. The microcrystals were allowed to settle in water without apparently dissolving, and single crystals appeared after 3 days (Scheme ). Those crystals of [CuCl2(4bpytm)2] were also obtained when the original compound 4.dmf was placed in a chamber at 50 °C with water for 10 days. On the basis of these observations, we think that the process of formation of this stable compound seems to involve dissolution of the initial coordination polymers, followed by the formation and crystallization of the new coordination polymer [CuCl2(4bpytm)2] from the solution phase. The organic molecule, lactic acid, was chosen as a model for modulating the pore size upon adsorption due to its simple structure and suitable size with hydrophobic and hydrophilic fragments. Nevertheless, the weak acid character of lactic acid was enough to achieve the protonation of 4bpytm ligand, and consequently, blue single crystals of [CuCl2(H4bpytm)2]Cl2 (3) were obtained when the desolvated materials were placed in acetone and lactic acid for 1 week. In all cases, the original metal−organic framework underwent a reorganization to give different compounds that despite the original material does not show apparent solubility in the most conventional solvents.

elements.content: Adsortion of different solvents was tried directly on 4.dmso compound. Water was incorporated into the pores, giving the green solid 4dmso·11H 2 O immediately, after leaving 4.dmso for 30 min in a suspension in water at room temperature. The water content was estimated by TGA and was confirmed by elemental analysis and IR. Full details of these processes are reported in the . Further studies aimed at understanding the porous activities of compounds 4.dmf and 4.dmso are underway.

elements.content: In the present paper, we have demonstrated the structural and chemical flexibility of the ligand 4bpytm and how it can be used to obtain different molecular associations and networks starting from the highly interpenetrated net in [CuCl2(4bpytm)2]. Interestingly, weakly coordinating ligands such as dmf or dmso modify noticeably the coordination sphere of the copper atom, but they are not strongly bonded to the metal. In fact, the solvent molecules generate channels along the crystal. On the other hand, the protonation of the ligand shows the rich structural activity of the N−H group in the formation of hydrogen bonds. This activity, together with the coordinated bond, contributes to the crystal packing of complexes 1, 2, and 3, and consequently, these systems could be considered as candidate building blocks to design materials based on both kinds of interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the present paper, we have demonstrated the structural and chemical flexibility of the ligand 4bpytm and how it can be used to obtain different molecular associations and networks starting from the highly interpenetrated net in [CuCl2(4bpytm)2]. Interestingly, weakly coordinating ligands such as dmf or dmso modify noticeably the coordination sphere of the copper atom, but they are not strongly bonded to the metal. In fact, the solvent molecules generate channels along the crystal. On the other hand, the protonation of the ligand shows the rich structural activity of the N-H group in the formation of hydrogen bonds. This activity, together with the coordinated bond, contributes to the crystal packing of complexes 1, 2, and 3, and consequently, these systems could be considered as candidate building blocks to design materials based on both kinds of interaction.

Concentrated HNO3 (2 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of 4bpytm (0.9 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of EtOH/H2O (20 mL). The solution was heated under reflux for 12 h, and the final pH was 0.26. Crystals were obtained after the mother liquor was stored for 1 day at 4 °C. Data: yield, 95%; mp 217 °C. Anal. calcd for C11H12N4S2O6: C, 36.4; H, 3.4; N, 15.2; S, 15.0%. Found: C, 36.4; H, 3.4; N, 15.5; S, 15.5%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3160−3000 b, 1578 s, 1487 m, 1472 m, 1381 s, 1201 m, 734 m, 486 m. 1H NMR (dmso-d 6, δ ppm): 5.34 [s, 2H, C(6)H2], 7.98 (d, 4H, H-2, H-5), 8.74 (s, 4H, H-3, H-4). 13C NMR (dmso-d 6, δ ppm): 40.1 C(6), 141.1 C(2) and C(5), 122.8 C(1), 158.6 C(3) and C(4).

H<sub>2</sub>4bpytm[CuCl<sub>4</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

Compound 1 was obtained by reaction of 4bpytm (0.137 g, 0.586 mmol) and CuCl2·2H2O (0.050 g, 0.293 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of water/absolute ethanol (20 mL). A 0.3 M concentration of HCl (3 mL) was added dropwise to the mixture to give a final pH of 1.25. The initial green precipitate was dissolved when HCl was added dropwise giving rise to a blue solution. This solution was stirred for 24 h. Orange crystals were obtained from the resulting solution by slow evaporation (6 days) at room temperature. Data: yield, 90%; mp 230 °C. Anal. calcd for C11H12Cl4N2S2Cu: C, 29.9; H, 2.7; N, 6.3; S, 14.5%. Found: C, 30.7; H, 2.8; N, 6.7; S, 15.0%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3182−2875 b, 1587 s, 1491 m, 1470 m, 1203 m, 735 m, 482 m.

[CuCl<sub>3</sub>(H4bpytm)(4bpytm)] (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution of 4bpytm (1.6 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was slowly added to a solution of CuCl2·2H2O (1 mmol) in methanol (7 mL). Oxalic acid (1 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was added to the reaction mixture. A green precipitate, containing oxalate and copper ions but with an undefined stoichiometry, was immediately filtered off. Single crystals of 2 were obtained from the resulting green solution by slow evaporation (2 days) at room temperature. Data: yield, 8%; mp 215 °C. Anal. calcd for C22H21N4S4Cl3Cu: C, 41.3; H, 3.3; N, 8.8; S, 20.0%. Found: C, 41.5; H, 3.4; N, 8.9; S, 20.4%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3074−2924 b 1594 s, 1535 m, 1481 m, 1202 m, 1019 m, 811 m, 731 m, 498 m.

[CuCl<sub>2</sub>(H4bpytm)<sub>2</sub>]·Cl<sub>2</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Compounds 4.dmso and 4.dmf were heated in an oven at 150 °C for 15 min/1 h (respectively) to give desolvated green powders. In each case, the powder (5 mg) was dissolved in acetone (10 mL) and lactic acid (1 mL, 11 mmol). Blue single crystals of 3 appeared after 3 days at room temperature. Data: mp 235 °C. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3404−2611 b, 1581 s, 1462 m, 1425 m, 1228 m, 1049 m, 808 m, 737 m, 502 m. Insufficient crystals were obtained for elemental analysis or a meaningful estimation of yield.

[CuCl<sub>2</sub>(4bpytm)]·2dmf (<bold>4.dmf</bold>)

4bpytm (0.213 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.213 mmol), dmf (4 mL), and EtOH (2 mL) were added to a Schlenk tube, which was then placed in a microwave oven. The mixture was irradiated for 90 s at 700 W. The resulting blue solution was allowed to cool down to room temperature, and blue crystals of 4.dmf were obtained rapidly. Data: yield, 90%; mp 229 °C. Anal. calcd for C17H24N4S2O2Cl2Cu: C, 39.6; H, 4.7; N, 10.9; S, 12.4%. Found: C, 39.5; H, 4.5; N, 10.6; S, 12.9%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3434 s, 1655 s, 1596 s, 1538 m, 1487 m, 1422 m, 1223 m, 1028 m, 809 m, 732 m, 504 m.

Thermal Stability and Structural Dynamics

The analysis of the crystal structures of 4.dmf and 4.dmso shows that the solvent molecules are located in channels that could allow the release of these solvent molecules. The thermogravimetric (TG) curves show similar weight loss behavior for both compounds with two successive events (). The first weight loss is assigned to the loss of trapped solvent molecules. Thermal analysis of 4.dmf shows that the first step starts at 130 °C with a weight loss of 26.6% and continues to 200 °C, which corresponds to the loss of two molecules of dmf (calcd 28.4%). The TGA study of 4.dmso shows a weight loss of 28.9% from 110 to 195 °C, which corresponds to two molecules of dmso (calcd 29.7%). The next weight loss occurred at 239 and 210 °C in 4.dmf and 4.dmso, respectively. At these temperatures, the metal−organic frameworks begin to decompose.
